message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The sustained sense of disequilibrium for 2 days, along with a horizontal nystagmus suggests Vestibular neuritis. The negative Dix-Hallpike maneuver rules out Benign paroxysmal positional vertigo. Meniere disease would manifest with hearing loss and tinnitus, and Vertebrobasilar stroke would have other neurological symptoms.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The dizziness and horizontal nystagmus suggest peripheral vestibular dysfunction, ruling out Vertebrobasilar stroke. The negative Dix-Hallpike maneuver suggests that it is not Benign paroxysmal positional vertigo, and Meniere disease typically involves unilateral hearing loss and tinnitus. Therefore, the most likely diagnosis is Vestibular neuritis.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The sustained sense of disequilibrium and horizontal nystagmus suggest vestibular neuritis, which can be caused by a viral infection. The negative Dix-Hallpike maneuver rules out BPPV, which is also a common cause of dizziness. Meniere disease would present with hearing loss, tinnitus, and vertigo attacks with associated nausea and vomiting. Vertebrobasilar stroke would have other neurological deficits and vertigo would be a less common symptom.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The sustained sense of disequilibrium along with horizontal nystagmus points to vestibular neuritis, an inflammation of the vestibular nerve. Benign positional vertigo can cause similar symptoms, but the Dix-Hallpike maneuver didn't provoke symptoms in this case. Meniere disease is characterized by recurrent episodes of vertigo, and Vertebrobasilar stroke typically presents with other neurological symptoms.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The sustained sense of disequilibrium and horizontal nystagmus suggest Vestibular neuritis as the most likely diagnosis. Other options have different symptoms, such as Meniere disease that has hearing loss and tinnitus, and Vertebrobasilar stroke that has sudden onset with other neurological symptoms. The negative Dix-Hallpike maneuver also suggests Vestibular neuritis as the culprit.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms and horizontal nystagmus suggest vestibular neuritis, an inflammation of the vestibular nerve. The Dix-Hallpike maneuver not provoking symptoms also supports this diagnosis. Benign paroxysmal positional vertigo would be provoked by the Dix-Hallpike maneuver. Meniere disease usually includes hearing loss and tinnitus, which are not described in this case. Vertebrobasilar stroke usually includes other neurological symptoms and a more acute onset.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The sustained sense of disequilibrium for 2 days, horizontal nystagmus, and negative Dix-Hallpike maneuver suggest vestibular neuritis. Benign paroxysmal positional vertigo would have a positive Dix-Hallpike maneuver, while Meniere disease and vertebrobasilar stroke would present with additional symptoms such as hearing loss, tinnitus, or neurological deficits. The patient's use of vitamin C is not relevant to the diagnosis.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The sustained sense of disequilibrium and horizontal nystagmus suggest vestibular neuritis, which is inflammation of the vestibular nerve. The Dix-Hallpike maneuver tests for benign paroxysmal positional vertigo, which is not the most likely diagnosis in this case. Meniere disease has episodes of vertigo accompanied by hearing loss, tinnitus, and ear fullness, which are not present in this case. Vertebrobasilar stroke typically presents with other neurologic symptoms beyond just dizziness.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The sustained sense of disequilibrium and horizontal nystagmus suggests vestibular neuritis. Meniere disease is characterized by fluctuating hearing loss and vertigo. Vertebrobasilar stroke usually presents with multiple neurological symptoms. The negative Dix-Hallpike maneuver also rules out benign paroxysmal positional vertigo.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The sustained sense of disequilibrium and horizontal nystagmus suggest vestibular dysfunction. The absence of symptoms during the Dix-Hallpike maneuver suggests it's not BPPV, and the lack of hearing loss and tinnitus rules out Meniere's disease. The absence of other neurological symptoms makes vertebrobasilar stroke less likely. Vestibular neuritis, which is inflammation of the vestibular nerve, is the most likely diagnosis in this case.
